lines.text: Why is it us? Why us?
Because we're here, lad. Nobody else. Just us.
Damn the levies man... Cowardly blacks!
What the hell do you mean "cowardly blacks?" They died on your side, didn't they? And who the hell do you think is coming to wipe out your little command? The Grenadier Guards?
The army doesn't like more than one disaster in a day.
Looks bad in the newspapers and upsets civilians at their breakfast.
Sixty! We dropped at least 60, wouldn't you say?
That leaves only 3,940.
It's a miracle.
If it's a miracle, Colour Sergeant, it's a short chamber Boxer Henry point 45 caliber miracle.
And a bayonet, sir, with some guts behind.
[Bourne calls the roll after the battle]
Hitch... Hitch, I saw you. You're alive.
I am? Oh, thanks very much.

[mounted, crossing stream]
Hot work?

[kneeling in stream]
Damned hot work.
Still, the river cooled you off a bit though, eh?
[pause]
Who are you?
John Chard, Royal Engineers.
Bromhead. 24th. That's my post... up there.
[points into middle distance]
You've come down from the column?
That's right. They want a bridge across the river.
Who said you could use my men?
They were sitting around on their backsides, doing nothing.
Rather you asked first, old boy.
I was told that their officer was out hunting.
Err... yes.
[spurs on horse]
I'll tell my man to clean your kit.
Don't bother!
No bother... I'm not offering to clean it myself! Still, a chap ought to look smart in front of the men, don't you think? Well chin-chin... do carry on with your mud pies.
Haven't you had enough? Both of you! My god, can't you see it's all over! Your bloody egos don't matter anymore. We're dead!
Chard. One of my men - Hook - do you know him?

[preoccupied]
No.
In the hospital, malingering under arrest. He's a thief, a coward and an insubordinate barrack room lawyer. And you've given him a rifle!

[distracted]
What?
In Queen's Regulations, it specifically states - Damn funny. Like a train... in the distance.
[stops as the sound of thousands of Zulu warriors marching toward the mission can be heard]
You were saying about Hook?

[of the Zulu]
How can they let themselves be married in droves like this - young girls to... to old men?
In Europe, young women accept arranged marriages with rich men. Perhaps the Zulu girls are luckier, getting a *brave* man.
A prayer's as good as bayonet on a day like this.
One thousand British soldiers have been massacred. While I stood here talking peace, a war has started.
Rourke's Drift... It'd take an Irishman to give his name to a rotten stinking middle o' nowhere hole like this.
Mr. Bourne, there should be 12 more men working on this redoubt.
They're very tired, sir.
[Chard whirls around]
I don't give a damn! And I want this wall nine feet high, firing steps on the inside. Form details to clear away the Zulu bodies, rebuild the south rampart, keep 'em moving! Do you understand?
Yes sir... very good, sir.
You know this boy?
Name is Cole, sir. He's a paper hanger.
Well, he's a dead paper hanger now.
Mr. Witt! When I have the impertinence to climb into your pulpit to deliver a sermon, then you can tell me my duty.

Death waits you! You have made a covenant with death, and with Hell you are in agreement. You're all going to die! Don't you realize? Can't you see? You're all going to die! Die! Death awaits you all!
Fire at will!
That's very nice of him.

[Throws Sergeant Maxfield across his shoulder]
Twenty eight days field punishment! No pay! You know what he did? Sent my money to my Missus.
[Slaps Sereant Maxfield's buttocks]
What did you do that for?
I belong to Natal Mounted Police.
Is that true then? He's a peeler, 716. Come to arrest the Zulus.

[doing roll call]
Hughes!
Excused duty!
[the soldiers begin to laugh]
No comedians, please. Hughes.
Yes, Colour Sergeant.
Well done, Adendorff, we'll make an Englishman of you yet!
No, thanks. I'm a Boer. The Zulus are the enemies of my blood. What are you doing here?
You don't object to our help, I hope?
It all depends on what you damned English want for it, afterwards.

[Adendorff has explained the classic Zulu 'buffalo' battle formation]
It looks er... jolly simple, doesn't it?
It's, er, jolly deadly, old boy.

[laughs]
Well done, Adendorff, we'll make an Englishmen of you yet!

[Quoting Psalm 46, v10-11 just before the battle]
I will be exalted among the heathen, I will be exalted in the earth. The Lord of Hosts is with us.
I hope so. As I live and die, I hope so.
Well, you've fought your first action.
Does everyone feel like this afterwards?
How do you feel?
Sick.
Well, you have to feel alive to feel sick.
You asked me, I told you.
[pause]
There's something else. I feel ashamed. Was that how it was for you? The first time?
The first time? You think I could stand this butcher's yard more than once?
I didn't know.
I came up here to build a bridge.

[both men are wounded but the soldier distributing ammunition has fallen]
Can you move your leg?

[flippantly]
If you want me to dance...
I want you to *crawl*. Come on you slovenly soldier, we've got work to do.
Heave! Put a bit more weight on that rope, you men!
He's even got a voice like a corporal!
Yeah, sort of like a female hippopotamus in labor.
Hey, Hooky... who's doing all that shooting? Who do you think?
Who do you think? Mister flamin' Bromhead, shooting flamin' defenseless animals for the flamin' officers' flamin' dinner.
You didn't say a thing to help, Bromhead.
Well, when you take command, old boy, you're on your own. One of the first things that the general - my grandfather - ever taught me.

[the Zulus are chanting before their final charge]
Do you think the Welsh can't do better than that, Owen?
Well, they've got a very good bass section, mind, but no top tenors, that's for sure.
What's he up to, 593?
Oh, I think he wants to be hero, 716.
Haven't you rednecks got names instead of numbers?

'Tis a Welsh regiment, man! Though there are some foreigners from England in it , mind. I am Jones from Bwlchgwyn, he is Jones from Builth Wells, and there are four more Joneses in C Company! Confusing, isn't it, Dutchy?
A Zulu regiment can run, *run*, 50 miles and fight a battle at the end of it.
Well, there's daft, it is then. I don't see no sense in running to fight a battle.

[At Maxfield, whom is singing in delirium]
Shut up you cripple!

[shouting, drunkenly]
He breaketh the bow and snappeth the spear in sunder!

[under his breath]
I shall be exalted among the 'eathens... I shall be exalted in the Earth.

[wounded]
You're the professional. Take command.
Now listen, old boy, you're not badly hurt. We need you! We need you! Understand?
You know what you've got there, my malingering Hector?
No, sir. Hook's the name, sir.

You've got a fine glistening boil, my friend. There's one glistening boil for every soldier in Africa. You may not get any medals in this campaign, Hook, but you'll certainly get more boils. For every gunshot wound I probe, I expect to lance 3 boils.
[brandishing a lance]
A spot of medicinal brandy would set me up, sir!
Brandy's for heroes, Mr. Hook. The rest of you will make do with boils on your skin, flies in your meat and dysentery on your bellies!

Why worry about a calf? I thought I was tired of farming. No adventure in it. But when you look at it, this country's not a bit as good as Bala and the lake there. Not really green, like. And the soil. There's no moisture in it. Nothing to hold a man in his grave.
I came here to build a bridge.
What's our strength?
Seven officers including surgeon, commissaries and so on; Adendorff now I suppose; wounded and sick 36, fit for duty 97 and about 40 native levies. Not much of an army for you.
Now there's a bitter pill. Our own damned rifles!
Orderly, damn it!, will you keep the flies away! Fan it! Damn you, Chard! Damn all you butchers!
[points towards the fleeing cavalry]
The way of the Lord has been shown to us!
You mean your only plan is to stand behind a few feet of mealie bags and wait for the attack?

[after being ordered to help prepare for the Zulu attack]
What for? Did I ever see a Zulu walk down the City road? No! So what am I doing here?
If 1200 men couldn't hold a defensive position this morning, what chance have we with 100?
[to the wounded Hook]
This is going to hurt you a lot more than it will me, I'm happy to say.
The Lord of Hosts is with us.
I hope so... as I live and die, I hope so.
You're no good to anyone, except the Queen and Sergeant Maxfield!
Well, thank you very much, the both of you!

[as Sergeant Maxfield raves deliriously in the hospital]
Stuff me with green apples! If a dog was as sick as him, they'd shoot it!

[shouting]
Front rank fire! Rear rank fire, reload!
[repeats a few times as one line of soldiers fires and the other kneels and reloads their rifles]
Good. I can find work for baritones as well as tenors.
[repeated line]
All right, nobody told you to stop working.
At one hundred yards! Volley fire, present! Aim! Fire!
It's fear dries the mouth, isn't it? When a man's as thirsty as this.
I could have drunk a river.
Owen!
Yes, Sergeant?
You've got a voice, haven't you?
Yes, baritone, Sergeant.
Well, get up on that hill and sing out if you see anything. You, too. And take your bandook, you dozy Welshman!
What do you know about Zulus?
Bunch of savages, isn't it?
The sentries report Zulus to the southwest. Thousands of them.
You slovenly soldier, Hitch.
Adendorff, what's wrong with them? Why don't they fight?
They're counting your guns.
*What?*
Can't you see that old boy up on the hill? He's counting your guns. Testing your firing power with the lives of his warriors.
Careful! Pop that chap somebody! Good fellow, good fellow!
Hooky, come on old boy, do something!
I'm excused duty.
Well, I haven't excused you, have I?
Oh, YOU want some help? Well, why didn't you say so?
[grabs a rifle and starts defending the mission]
The Good Book says "What did she go out into the wilderness to see, a man dressed in fine clothes?"
Why do they carry those little daggers, Father?
It is a symbol of their chastity.
Would you kill your brother, boy?
Colour Sergeant Bourne! What's that shooting?
A rifle, Hughes.
Eh?
If you're sick in hospital, I'd suggest you go and lie down.
Yes, Colour Sergeant.
